sub_topic: Interpolation and extrapolation of data using Lagrange polynomials
message_1:
Suppose you have some experimental data on the temperature of a substance at different times $t$ as shown in the following table:

| $t$ (minutes) | Temperature (degrees Celsius) |
|---------------|--------------------------------|
| 0             | 20                             |
| 10            | 30                             |
| 20            | 50                             |
| 30            | 70                             |
| 40            | 90                             |

Using Lagrange polynomial interpolation, estimate the temperature of the substance at $t=25$. Also, using Lagrange polynomial extrapolation, estimate the temperature of the substance at $t=50$.
message_2:
To estimate the temperature at $t=25$ and $t=50$, we will use Lagrange polynomial interpolation and extrapolation. The general formula for the Lagrange polynomial is:

$$
P(t) = \sum_{i=0}^{n} L_i(t) \cdot y_i
$$

where $L_i(t)$ is the Lagrange basis polynomial:

$$
L_i(t) = \prod_{j=0, j\neq i}^{n} \frac{t - t_j}{t_i - t_j}
$$

and $y_i$ is the temperature at time $t_i$.

For our data, we have 5 points, so $n=4$. Let's calculate the Lagrange basis polynomials for each point:

$L_0(t) = \frac{(t-10)(t-20)(t-30)(t-40)}{(0-10)(0-20)(0-30)(0-40)}$

$L_1(t) = \frac{(t-0)(t-20)(t-30)(t-40)}{(10-0)(10-20)(10-30)(10-40)}$

$L_2(t) = \frac{(t-0)(t-10)(t-30)(t-40)}{(20-0)(20-10)(20-30)(20-40)}$

$L_3(t) = \frac{(t-0)(t-10)(t-20)(t-40)}{(30-0)(30-10)(30-20)(30-40)}$

$L_4(t) = \frac{(t-0)(t-10)(t-20)(t-30)}{(40-0)(40-10)(40-20)(40-30)}$

Now, we can calculate the temperature at $t=25$ using interpolation:

$P(25) = L_0(25) \cdot 20 + L_1(25) \cdot 30 + L_2(25) \cdot 50 + L_3(25) \cdot 70 + L_4(25) \cdot 90$

$P(25) \approx 57.8125$

So, the estimated temperature at $t=25$ is approximately 57.81 degrees Celsius.

Next, we can calculate the temperature at $t=50$ using extrapolation:

$P(50) = L_0(50) \cdot 20 + L_1(50) \cdot 30 + L_2(50) \cdot 50 + L_3(50) \cdot 70 + L_4(50) \cdot 90$

$P(50) \approx 142.5$

So, the estimated temperature at $t=50$ is approximately 142.5 degrees Celsius.
